page.title: 08SEAFIELD COLLIERY, KIRKCALDY
page.content: Seafield Colliery is the deepest mine in Scotland and one of the largest undersea mines in Europe. All of the tunnels run under Kirkcaldy Bay, and in fact Seafield is linked to its sister colliery, Frances, in the north of Kirkcaldy by undersea tunnels. There are three main tunnels 1\-2 miles long, as well as a large number of smaller tunnels. Water continually seeps into the tunnels and, of course, has to be pumped clear. The deepest tunnel in Seafield is 1000 metres below the surface, at the deepest point. There are two shafts each 600 metres deep. One of these is used to bring up the coal, and the other to transport supports and other materials as well as the miners themselves.
